claim: When users struggle, blame the design, not the user. Good design makes correct actions obvious via discoverability, feedback, and aligned conceptual models.
rationale: High 'human error' rates signal design flaws; machines should understand people, not vice versa.

claim: Never solve the problem as stated; it’s usually a symptom. First find the real problem.
rationale: A brilliant solution to the wrong problem is worse than none; double diamond = find right problem before right solution.

claim: Use natural mapping: arrange controls in the same spatial layout as what they control.
rationale: Spatial analogies give immediate understanding (e.g., seat-shaped seat controls need no instructions).

claim: Feedback must be immediate, informative, and prioritized; too little or too much both fail.
rationale: Feedback communicates results/state; generic beeps and delays cause confusion or get ignored.

claim: Featuritis: adding features endlessly creates complex, unusable, homogenized products.
rationale: Competitive/feature-request pressure bloats products; true need focus prevents homogenization.

claim: Mode errors: same controls mean different things in different states; avoid modes or make them obvious.
rationale: Users forget mode (e.g., flight systems, alarm clocks); confusion causes dangerous errors.

claim: Automation fails silently and leaves humans out of the loop; humans respond too slowly when not engaged.
rationale: If automation changes mode or fails without notice, humans miss it (e.g., cruise ship grounding).

claim: Use forcing functions (interlocks, lock-ins, lockouts) to prevent incorrect/unsafe actions.
rationale: Constraints (keys, door interlocks, save prompts, child caps) prevent errors but must be used judiciously.

claim: Apply Five Whys; accidents have multiple causes (Swiss Cheese model). Seek root causes beyond human error.
rationale: Multiple failures align to cause incidents; root cause analysis must go deeper than immediate action.

claim: Make actions reversible with Undo; allow multiple levels and auto-save to enable recovery.
rationale: Design should anticipate error and ease recovery; confirmations should be smart and cancellable.

claim: Complexity is fine; confusion is not. Provide clear conceptual models to tame complexity.
rationale: Life is complex; clear structure makes complexity usable (like organized kitchens).

claim: Double diamond: diverge/converge on the right problem, then diverge/converge on the right solution.
rationale: Resist premature convergence; discover real problem before solution; still honor schedules for convergence.

claim: OXO tools: designed for arthritic hands, marketed as 'better for everyone'—inclusive design success.
rationale: Inclusive design removes stigma and serves all users; there is no average person.

claim: Toyota Jidoka/Poka-Yoke: empower stopping lines, error-proof with asymmetrical holes; systemic prevention.
rationale: Admitting errors and designing them out yields continuous improvement and safety.

claim: Tenerife collision: 583 deaths from stacked factors (time/economic pressure, hierarchy, poor comms) not single cause.
rationale: Swiss Cheese model: multiple aligned failures cause disasters; no single human error explains it.
